Description: Globular glass flask in the form of a pomegranate. Clear brown with opaque white and opaque orange trails.Splayed rim formed by six triangular, pointed calyx-tips, bent outwards; cylindrical neck joining shoulder at angle; almost spherical body with rounded bottom; repaired from fragments; three calyx tips broken away. On body two groups of opaque combed trails: (a) on upper half, three trails, orange, white, and orange, combed into upright festoons; (b) on lower half, three trails, white, orange, and white, combed into inverted festoons. Core-formed and tooled, trails marvered and combed.
Curator's comments: The attribution to Tomb A5 is based on the description of the intact deposit in Welch's letter on 16 June 1899. Fossing 1940, 28 (claiming it, wrongly, as a sixth example in the BM from Enkomi). Harden 1964, 19, fig. 1a. Astrom 1967, 58, 125 (=id. 1972, 530, 597). Harden 1969, 48, pi. ii, D. Barag 1970, 185 (ascribing it to Paphos, following an erroneous attribution in GR dept register, now corrected).
Bibliographic references: Glass / Catalogue of Greek and Roman Glass in the British Museum (13)
Malmgren 2003 / Klavdhia-Tremithos. A Middle and Late Cypriote Bronze Age site. (no. 144, p.55)
Peltenburg 1986 / Ramesside Egypt and Cyprus (p. 153, no. 23)
Jacobsson 1994 / Aegyptiaca from Late Bronze Age Cyprus (No. 141)
Condition: Broken and mended, lower part of body partly restored in plaster; one calyx-tip lost in antiquity, two others during or since excavation. On rim, neck and upper half of body a thick whitish enamel-like coat of weathering; on lower half an iridescent surface film only.
